This is the most advanced vr system. Great for kids and adults. Work in your virtual office, watch a movie or be IN the games you play. This is my 4th purchase. I had to get one for my hubby, my bff and my grandkids.

Excellent, customer support in store, Best Buy is my Only Electronic Shop.  I brought   myGalaxy Note 10+  , my wife buy, Apple 11 pro max  on 2019 samsung TV Q70, on 2020 My quest2 Headset and my sony A7RIII on 2021

I love the VR world, but to me I find the oculus store having a lack of games/apps but you can use 3rd party sites to find more. I also think it's kinda blurry and find myself readjusting it to my face fairly often.

This is great for all my kids. Something for everyone. The fun is endless. Great customer service and fast delivery. Easy setup. The white straps on the headset get dirty easily so I would prefer black for the kids.

From the start of the setup it looked pretty good. Only to be let down by Autification of my Facebook couldn't get passed the login also i didn't like the way the controller's feel in your hands and not rechargeable

The advancements in VR are amazing. You get immersed in the game in no time. After playing this you will fully understand the videos of people running into walls, screaming and falling down. It’s a great experience!

The device came packaged very well. The instructions on how to operate aren't very easy to understand. I had watched a youtube video to assist. Highly recommend. The Oculus itself is fun and easy to use once set up.

VR is so insanely lifelike, even though it looks nothing like the real world when you're in there.  You can get lost for hours in the VR world, be careful.  Really fun, I would suggest everyone try it at least once.

Pros: Super fun, I like I can do a variety of things like social media, video games, watch TV
Cons: can only play for a limited time before getting a headache. 
Review from a teenager who the gift was purchased for.

Bought this item for my husband for Christmas. Overall he loves it, one huge downfall especially for what you Pay for device is the fact of how much you pay for the games. Almost comparable to having a gaming system

Great entry point into VR. Some people I've let try it still get some motion sickness, but it's far less common than early VR was. The games available are great, though being tethered to Facebook is a bit annoying.

No pc required. Games are not expensive. Be aware of vr sickness though. Yes it is a thing and will most likely happen for the first couple times using the headset. Invest in a longer charging chord from the start.

Really fun experience…I am new to the VR world. It it has been fun to explore this new way of entertainment. Do yourself a favor and buy the more comfortable head strap. Otherwise it becomes a little uncomfortable.

Blew expectations out of the water. Works perfectly and fits comfortably if you adjust it to your head properly. Can easily wear it for the entire duration of the battery life with no discomfort. It is a ton of fun

This VR headset is and feels amazing to use! I would recommend this product to anyone who wants to dip their hands into virtual reality, easy to use, easy to setup and also not being tied down by cables is awesome!

Super fun, easy to set up. Can cast to a compatible TV to show people what you’re doing in VR. Party mode while playing ping pong with friends who are 1000’s of miles away is cool. Top Golf and Beat Sabers are fun!

Grandson totally loves this, he saved for months to buy it. He is hardly ever doing anything else but playing this, which is not good. He says that it is worth the price. But I say it takes up too much of his life.

We gave this to my son for his 19th birthday. He sent the next 3 weeks using it daily. He loves this headset and really enoys the games that he has been playing. He was excited to bring it back to college with him.

So much fun!! For someone who’s never used VR this stuff is amazing. Downloaded a fishing game and a boxing game, talk about an unexpected workout (in a great way) if you’re on the fence don’t be! Worth every penny

Excellent VR experience every time, pretty easy to use.  Purchased for my husband, i didn't think i would like it but it really is a lot of fun.  Worth it, wish i had purchased the one with the most GB's of memory.

Bought this because my dad had one and it was a ton of fun. The only thing I don't like is that you have to log in with a Facebook account and it's a little difficult to adjust the headstrap if you don't know how.

All I can say is if you can afford one get it ! For all ages old , or young . Internet connection needed and a Facebook account to activate. Get oculus first steps for free and start there . Happy VRING EVERYONE !

When i placed the orders to be shipped to my children up in North, you informed everyday with the progress of the shipping via email. I am so impressed with your efforts with the status. I wish you happy holidays!

Great product at a good price too. I love everything about it. Gaming, watching movies, videos, or just browsing the web all in 3D without a tv. More content would be nice but new stuff is coming out all the time.

Very intuitive, and easy to use.  Controller batteries last forever, and headset charges quickly.  Lots of games and video content, but I wish the resolution was better, but that's likely due to the video content.

We’ve bought an embarrassing number of these in the last year as gifts and for our family, definitely love but it has its limitations in the weight/structure of the headset and battery life.  Still fun and unique.

We love our VR set!  The graphics are amazing and so life like that in some instances, I had to sit down!!  if you have a real fear of heights, be careful.  Otherwise, we're enjoying the activities and adventures.

I had the older version of this which is no longer supported.  This one is fantastic.  Seems to be quicker and smoother when playing.  Controllers seem to work a bit better as well.  Very happy with this purchase.

Can't say enough about this very fun and immersive! Great choices for apps as well as games and interfacing remotely to lap top or computer is seemless! Wife and I both love this and are probably getting another!

Bought this for my eight year old autistic granddaughter  although experts don’t recommend this for her age I must say this has helped her focus more I’m so happy that I did no regrets fits her head perfectly too

After buying one for my son for Christmas and trying it out for myself I had to get one. Extremely fun and addicting. Had my fiance try it and she wanted one immediately. She uses the exercise apps every morning.

Love it!  Gift for my son for his birthday. After having a turn 3 different people were wanting one of their own including me. So much fun
Best Buy had awesome online service and free fast shipping. Very pleased.

Got this so my partner and I could play games together while she was traveling. There isn't a huge crossover between this and PSVR but it certainly worked. If you're interested in VR this is a great way to start.

Really enjoying the oculus 2. I have the rift so upgrading to this was a no brainer when this version came out to replace the 64GB. It's fantastic, fun, good exercise and so much better not be tethered to my PC.

I love it overall. Dont like that shared accounts cant cast or connect to phone app. I wish I would have known that only the admin can do that. If this problem ever gets addressed I will definatley give 5 stars.

Great vR. Love this toy. But I wish the quality was better. They are cool. I think it’s the content out there. But overall all. Great headset plus the value is great. I would buy again. Wish more people had one.

Item itself is pretty cool and well built. But when you put it on to play and try looking around head starts spinning like crazy and that doesn’t go away for couple hours. Because of this had to return the item.

This isn’t “perfect” VR but it’s definitely amazing for what it is.  All the cartoony games I’ve played have been great.  Even the tutorial was lots of fun!  So much detail in everything I’ve experienced so far.

Not a bad system but very vulnerable to sweat. Will mess up the display if you swear heavy and wear it too long. This is marketed as a fitness product so you'd think sweat wouldn't play a factor but not it does.

So fun, at the new 128GB size it was a no brainer to finally make this purchase. Sure, there will be a new version coming soon but this packs a lot of bang for the buck. Very fun to play with family and friends.

Bought as a gift for my daughter. She loved it and immediately 3set it up to work with Steam games. Only issue is the extras you might have to buy like the $80 USB cord if you can't get it to link to your wifi.

Got my oculus 2 delivered and arrived in a day. Had a quick easy set up. And myself and my kids where using the product for hours. And still are using it everyday. Iam impressed by the tech and how easy to use.

Got for my 12 year old for Christmas. He really enjoys it. 1 thing I disliked was that I had to create a Facebook account for this thing. The app feature to buy games from and sync to actual head set is smooth.

Been one of the coolest purchases ive made, great entertainment and some fun games. A lot of fun with friends only downside is a short battery life, either buy the extended battery or get a long charging cable.

Overall it’s a good headset. I gave it 4 stars because I think they can upgrade the lenses a bit better. Please add another space setting for eyes. It does at times feel like you’re looking through a fish bowl.

I finally decided to pull the trigger on this device and let me tell you that I don’t regret it. It is what I expected for a good entertainment device. It takes you to another world of video gaming experience..

I purchased this for my grandson, was worried it was going to be to complicated for him, but this VR system is easy to use and setup. Image quality is very good and controls are accurate with little to no lag.

Bought this as a Christmas present for my 14 year old son, and I enjoy it as much as him. Will say some games do make me dizzy and others I have no issues with. So it depends on the games how intense they are.

I had a very pleasant shopping experience. I was Christmas shopping and trying to find a game system for my kids and everyone was sold out. I went to Best Buy thinking they were sold out too but they were not.

Setp takes some work, but its well worth it. My 13yo twins were quickly off exploring the games I'd loaded. Mission ISS and Echo VR were big hits. They didnt touch their phones all night, which was remarkable.

In the world if woulda coulda shoulda 
Run don't walk to Yes!!! Everyone needs to experience this Oculus. It is truly worth every dime plus! Like Mikey used to say Try it You will Like it!!!!! No regrets here.

The Oculus Quest 2 was a present for my niece(13). They've played Job Simulator and Beat Saber siBnce they opened it up and downloaded the games.  Hoping I didn't make a mistake only getting the 128GB Oculus!

Very convenient not having cords that connect to a PC. When paired with the Oculus link cable, works almost identically to the Rift S. Downside is that it requires your PC to have a USB type C port available.

Good product. Have been using it for 2 months now and I have had great experience. Usually use it for a hour or two max. I hope for more game and app development to happen to provide more value in the future.

Excellent VR system. Hard to believe how immersed you can get by being in the “virtual “ world. Great price for what the Quest brings to the table. Not just for children. Plenty of apps for adults to get into

Pretty cool but motion sickness pills required for most. 
All VR needs another decade to develop. It has the potential to be awesome (unlike 3D) but it is cool if u have $300 in the 1 w w3disposable income..

I purchased this for my 12 year old daughter. The whole family loves it and fights over who’s turn it is to play. I wish the battery lasted longer but it meets my expectations for this type of gaming system.

I have both the Quest 2 and the Rift S....the mobility and ease of in - and - out gameplay is unmatched.  Only downside is the amount of charging I have to do with the headset...other than that...it's great.

The virtual reality is amazing! But for us old folks it takes a minute to get used to it. I myself need to clear out the room before playing, or I’d be falling over everything. It was a good buy! Lots of fun

My son loves this.  Exactly what he was expecting.  Only issue is that he is sensitive to motion sickness and some games can trigger it.  Those games that are uncomfortable can be refunded easily.  Worth it!

It’s fun when I can get it to work. So far, on 3 of the games I’ve bought, I can’t get past the first screen (“Disclaimer “ or “Choose language”) to play the actual game. Very disappointed. May take it back.

The lag is unreal and the controllers started drifting after a week of having it. It is impossible to use the headset for a long peroid of time unless you replace the straps. For $300+ I expected a lot more.

Gaming is so much smoother than the PS4 VR. Only complaint I have is the controllers are easy to throw, but you can use hand tracking to control games that don't need buttons, and it's still pretty accurate.

Gaming is so much smoother than the PS4 VR. Only complaint I have is the controllers are easy to throw, but you can use hand tracking to control games that don't need buttons, and it's still pretty accurate.

The headset is pretty fun to play with, but it is sometimes hard to find the perfect vision so that it's not blurry. Also, I do have motion sickness related to some games in the quest 2, so just be careful!

Well worth the money. You cannot find a better preforming vr headset for less. The fact that you can play completely untethered from a PC makes it the first real VR set that appeals to a majority of people.

I bought this for my son and I have to say this thing is really cool. It feels very lifelike and he is enjoying it till no end. One thing I have to say which is why I didn’t give it 5 stars is the initial set up took longer than it should have. After some minor information and connecting to the internet it wants you to download the app to your phone or tablet, then you have to sign in using a FB account. If you don’t have one it prompts you to create one. Then you have to link the app to the headset. There’s also a lengthy firmware update that took about 5-10 minutes. I think the whole thing of creating a FB account stinks because my son did not have one and had no interest in having one but you can’t play without one. They should allow you to just create an Oculus account and move on. I’m sure this is part of Mark Zuckerberg plan to have more FB accounts but it’s pretty lame. If you already have FB then I guess it would have been a less painful set up. Games are cheaper than the other video games, they range from 15-30 dollars and you can order them on the VR set or on the app

Used this for one day and it went crazy. It just spins around looking for the controllers. I master reset it and still broke. When I returned it there were several people taking theirs back for same reason.

Greatest experience ever.  I purchased it for my grandson for Christmas tried it out fell 8n love and purchased another one for him and kept the one I opened. I’ve sold 2 already.  My daughter and my niece.

This is simply amazing.  I bought it from my grandson for his birthday and we have to pull him out of them.  He's up moving around instead of sitting at the computer.  Just make sure you have space.   hehe

I purchased this for my Grandson who is 15 yrs old. I never thought he would get so involved with it as he has. He's playing with others and having a great time . He loves it !! so glad I got it for him .!

Super fun. Great games that don’t break the bank. It’s a little iffy with steam but once I figured it out just restarting pc and headset will fix any link issue most of the time. You can’t go wrong for 300

So much worth the money!
Besides all the VR games, you can play youtube VR, youtube in theatre mode, netflix in theatre mode.
In the future, you may also connect it with PC VR games. It has huge potential.

The Oculus Quest 2 Virtual Reality Headset has made VR Gaming and the new Metaverse accessible to everyone.  It is completely wireless, comfortable and sells for less than a comparable non-VR game console.

This is so much fun to play with. Our entire family loves it. Games are easy to download and you can even find your friends and interact with them.  I would highly recommend buying an Oculus for Best Buy.

a tad heavy and fogs up when playing.  The graphics are pretty decent. the controllers go through batteries pretty quickly. Had to return for new once since one controller went bad within t he first month

This was a gift for my son and he loves it. The picture is great and he can talk to other people while playing, which is fun for him. Games are a decent cost, especially compared to other gaming consoles.

After owning the first version of Quest, and loving it upgrading just made me live it even more! Bestter resolution, and frame rates keep pushing this platform in to the mainstream! This is the way to go!

Fun for the entire family and no need for extra equipment. We take this on our family travels. Fun fun fun and i have several meditation and relaxation activities. We absolutely love it!!

my daughter loves this.  She is in a wheelchair and has difficulty traveling but has been able to see many of the wonders of the world for free and she says it feels like she is there.

This is something I’ve always wanted to try and I’m glad I did ! Simply put , this thing is Amazing ! A easy to use all in one VR set . Oculus (or Meta) has done a wonderful job making a quality product and a pretty impressive experience. It seems to have something for everyone. The controls are pretty intuitive and seem to track well for all the games I’ve played thus far. Battery life is ok as is the comfort of the included head strap . It is definitely worth upgrading to the better strap with built in battery, this is a must . I personally experienced some degree of dizziness but it quickly passed. Something to note ; the Oculus store has a policy on most of the games it sells , if you experience motion sickness and have played the game for less than 2 hours, you can get a refund! One more thing, as of this time, you must have a Facebook account to use this . It’s not a big deal as you can change  All of your privacy settings so whatever you do on Oculus is not all over Facebook. I have no regrets about this purchase, it’s been pretty amazing so far and look forward to what’s ahead for VR . The whole family loves it !
This was an awesome buy. The whole family enjoys the oculus, even my 82 year old mother. They have plenty of free things to do as well as great games to purchase.

Purchased this so our son could do a baseball training app.  I struggled to give it 4 stars and not 3.  First, its dependent upon Facebook to operate.   Facebook went down and the headset wouldn't work.  It seems like they would have this operating separately and not dependent on it.  Also the headset has been glitchy since the crash that happened at Facebook. The battery life on it isn't the greatest but fortunately you can attach an external pack.  Laat but not least is the app store.  I browse through it and I feel as if i dont see all of the games.  I typed a few in search to find but i didnt see those games when I went to Browse All.

Now you're wondering why 4 stars then.  Well it's because its still pretty neat.  My son can train and take BP in the garage whenever he wants.  Although there seems to be a lack of blockbuster games so far, there are still some cool games in the store.  Also you can expand the library by using as PCVR.  I like to tinker so you can modify the headset to how you like it.  So far we've added a halo headstrap but will do a battery pack and RX lenses in it.  So for $299 its a pretty cool item.

The Oculus Quest 2, is as basic as any Virtual Reality ( VR) Headset could be, while it does offer advanced features not offered by most off brand headsets, these features, show little promise in anything that isn’t on its main menu.

Hand Tracking- For apps that people would want hand tracking to be used for, is not available on. Hand Tracking is slow, and movement is very off time if you move your hands quickly as the outside cameras fail to properly catch your movement.

AirLink- Mediocre at best? It offers a very interactive and open system to which you’re freely available to play offline listed games which refers to games on different platforms, an example being steam. 
Offers an unstable fps, and most games completely crash even when the pc being used is more than capable of running the specific games, this evidence was provided by steams VR Performance Test.


Fit: Decent fit, if you’re working out make sure you tighten it or else it will fly off your head, it is very bouncy and hard to tighten at that.


Battery; Battery is very sensitive, if you don’t immediately remove the battery after it reaches 100% you run the risk of damaging your battery.

After reading so many FB comments *I barely go on FB* I convinced myself I would never be able to figure out how to get it to work when it arrives. Doom, Gloom and a lot of Zoom - if I couldn't figure this out by myself I was out a lot of money! By the way, has anyone else notice the huge price comarison of the Quest? Anywhere from $299 - $699 for the same Oculus Quest 2? Anyway, jus sayin...

Today - It finally arrived and boy was I terrified opening the box. I stared, should I send it back - can I do this... well, a long time later I did it, I tore the plastic and out came my Oculus Quest 2 with two cool controllers.

Within 15 minutes I was hooked up to WiFi, FB and playing tennis. I got tired and did meditation for 10 minutes just floating in space. The realty is - its plain awesome! It looked so real that I found myself suddenly afraid of heights! Then it was time to charge the quest - which took around 2 hours.

Yes, it was that easy!!! I love it! So, lesson to everyone - if I can do it all by MYSELF you can too - because you are awesome! Especially if you reading my review. Thanks!

A quick note: You have the option to move the eye piece to make you vision clearer. The eye piece does not rotate. You must take your thumbs and slide right or left.

This thing is WAY too cool!! Very easy to set up, very intuitive process. My 13yr old son set it up, I just had to link it to my Facebook account, then we were done. You have to download games. There are MANY to choose from depending upon your tastes - first person shooter games, fitness type games, etc. The graphics are incredible, with VERY realistic 3-D VR imaging. I'm not a big fan of heights and this thing tricks me into thinking I am at heights. It can be downright frightening, that is how realistic it can be! The audio / sound is top notch, whether playing music or whatever during the games. It is truly a very immersive experience. We only have one in our house and that is going to change since me and my two boys are always scrambling to play it. If you are into gaming or know someone who is, this is a must have item.

Warning - this is very realistic. If you get car sick, motion sick, suffer bouts of vertigo, and or have inner ear or other balance/stability issues - this will definitely trigger those. The depth and motion clarity it combines in its 3D VR graphics are absolutely amazing. It makes you feel like you are physically there, hence the meaning behind VR. I don't like heights too much and I got light headed with cold sweats during one game where we were riding high altitude coasters.

My daughter had one and loved it.  After giving hers a try, I had to get one.  The experience is very immersive.  As a matter of fact, the first game I played was the Darth Vader (Star Wars) one and I was completely blown away with just how realistic and immersive it was.  (Although, the game was rather short.  Part 1 took me maybe an hour to complete.  Not a criticism of the Oculus, obviously, but be aware that gaming experiences are not always like those on a traditional gaming console or computer regarding the "depth" or length of the experience.)  The controls are intuitive, for the most part (and there is a tutorial included within the unit that you can go through help become acquainted with the unit).  The focus does not always appear to be perfect when looking around, but overall that is a minor annoyance that does not detract from the experience.  The unit is also comfortable for the most part, but after gaming for a while you do notice the weight and the "pressing" of the unit against your face.  Along those lines, the "seal" around the unit may not necessarily fit every size face perfectly.  Toward the bottom, around the nose, I do get a little light bleeding in.  Lastly, I tried the International Space Station simulation and it did make me a little woozy (I did not have that issue with the Darth Vader game).  The experience is very realistic, but motion sickness can be a very real side effect with some games.

Gamer since the Nintendo and Sega days. Currently on the Xbox Series X.  My VR experience has always been at Dave and Busters or Main Event. Few at the mall. Used those goggles with your phone too. I thought VR was trash, dull and polygonal. 

Got this thing and wow. NO HYPE this thing has bright and colorful graphics. I've played SKYRIM, SYNTH RIDERS, WALKING DEAD, AND PAVLOV and I get immersed and lose track of my surrounding. 

*Helpful tip* Battery life depends on graphics and game. Average about 2 hours. Buy a 6' cord (USB-A to USB-C), and a slim battery power bank that fits in a back pocket. You now turned 2 hours of gameplay to 4 hours or more depending on your battery bank. Can be done as little as $20-30. I use a 4kmah battery. Gives me 2 hours of gameplay.

This thing is so cool. VR is about to take over. Especially at this price range. I love that you can connect to your PC and play PC VR games wirelessly with AIR LINK at no extra cost! I read before you had to buy an app.  If you want to entertain, connect to AIR LINK with your PC, hook up your TV HDMI to PC and entertain your friends and family watching you play or explore. 

What I dont like is that there's a small SWEET SPOT in the goggles. If you're not in it, then it gets blurry. Wish the sweet spot was bigger I guess. Have to adjust every now and then back in it. 

If you're going to cry about having to sign up with Facebook. Make a new profile just for gaming. Duh!

This is the best standalone headset on the market right now (jan 2022. The resolution is one of the highest on the market right now, and with the experimental 120hz refresh rate, the visual quality is very good. The controllers are alright, however the thumb tracking could use some work, and without using a controller cover, they are an absolute sweat and grease magnet. The headset can also be linked to your pc with a link cable, although I would not recommend the official oculus cable; it is overpriced and is not a noticeable enough improvement to be worth it for me. Pcvr works great, however the battery can still drain while using it, unless you have enough power going to your usb port, and if you don't have a usb 3.0 or 3.1 cable, battery while in pcvr might be an issue. 

The headset does have a few downsides, like the uncomfortable strap that it comes with out of the box. If you plan to play for more than an hour or two, I would definitely upgrade. The facial interface is also not the best, because it absorbs sweat like a sponge. The included silicone cover works okay, but I would definitely recommend upgrading. One of the biggest drawbacks of the Quest 2 is that there are only three IPD (Inter-pupillary distance) settings. If your IPD is one of these settings (58mm, 63mm, or 68mm), than this won't be an issue for you. If your eyes don't fall at or near one of these settings, you might have some issues with clarity. 

Overall, this is a very good headset for the price, and definitely recommended.

I guess if you use it as a complement device to your PC to get a VR experience in games you play than it might be worth it. But as a standalone product (as FB currently actively advertises it) it is mostly a geek toy. My kids had some fun initially, first few days, with Beat Saber, RecRoom, some other games, but they became bored very fast and quickly went back to Roblox and other games on their laptops. Yes, it is fun for friends gatherings as entertainment, but since you can't play together and you need a lot of space, it is not ideal. The traditional console is much better. My sound had a birthday recently. We had an Xbox Series S and this Oculus, and although every kid on the party tried Oculus once or twice, and one (5yo) kid really liked it, most quickly switched to XBox. Oculus does have a novelty factor, but the selection of games is very poor. Some videos are cool, like the one narrated by David Attenborough, but in general - not there yet. And apps/games are so outrageously expensive. Doing physical exercises app has a subscription of $19 per month! Not one-time payment, but MONTHLY subscription. Maybe it is fun to try it, but exercising with big something on your head isn't such a great experience, and I don't many will continue to do it after a couple of extensive sessions. Apple Fitness plus provide much more for less money, and better integration with other Apple devices, including AW.  
So yeah, you can spend $299 on Oculus, but expect it to spend most of the time on your self or in the closet

I love my Oculus Quest 2 Advanced All-In-One Virtual Reality Headset - 128GB.  I can play games in the Oculus store as well as games from SteamVR on the PC.  I'm coming from the Samsung Gear VR, so this is an upgrade.  

There are lots of reasons to commend it. First, the price point is accessible. Second, the availability of games is plentiful and growing. Third, the accessories you can purchase to make your experience more personalized are vast, and many are reasonably priced.  Finally, the headset is rich with features to make socializing fun, like casting to the Oculus app on the phone or to your PC.

Please don't think you must have the 256 GB version to have room for the games you play.  Some experiences will be once in a blue moon experiences, and there will be no need to keep them on your headset.  They can be downloaded on demand when you get a taste for the app again.  More frequently played apps can easily be hosted on your headset with room to spare for many folks.

The one con, and it's a major one for me, is that you must have a Facebook account to use the Oculus headset.  One of the reasons this is a problem was made evident when Facebook and its holdings went dark recently.  Nobody could access Oculus.

A word of advice for folks new to VR, use your hand straps on your controller.  If you don't, I promise you that you will drop or throw your controllers at some point.  Been there.  Don't that.  Let's hope you don't send your controller flying through something like your TV or your friend's eyeglasses.

I  put off getting a VR headset for a long time because I didn't think it would be worth the price. 

Got it on special. 

It is one of the greatest experiences with technology you can have! It does an amazing job at completely immersing you into environment you are viewing. 

There are several apps that are free to use on it, but be prepared to dish out hundreds of dollars for a better experience. 

I would have given it 5 stars, but here are the cons that made me lower my rating:

This is owned by Facebook. A multi-billion dollar company. You would expect nothing but the best. Yet there are several re-occurring glitches.

1. Sometimes, it randomly gives an error that "tracking" has stopped working and it won't let you do anything. You would have to restart to get it working again.
2. Once in a while, you'll get an error: Oculus Assistant stopped working. Again you have to restart and hopefully that resolves it.
3. Sometimes its hard to indicate what the "floor" is. You can press reset, but it still wont detect the floor properly. It should be easier to do this.
4. You don't have absolute freedom in choosing what position you need to be in when wearing the headset. Eg. You can't always just lay down and see everything properly. It depends on the app if they allow it. Sometimes, you want to watch something in 360 while laying down.
5. Should have a quick button that activates the cameras so you can pause your interaction and view your surroundings quickly. I hate having to remove the headset to quickly see something around me.

I've played on other VR headsets before but I never purchased one myself because I never felt they were quite there yet. When I heard this one was not only standalone, but could be used on the PC, was 120hz, is completely wireless and only 300 dollars I couldn't believe that all the complaints I had had been addressed. Another big selling point for Oculus vs the Vive is having access to both the Oculus store and Steam available to play games on PC.

The two main things I had worried about when comparing online, resolution and tracking accuracy, have not been an issue at all. Could the resolution be better? Absolutely, but it is more than good enough to fully enjoy any title you play. The accuracy, however, is a different story. I've only had very slight issues with the tracking and it hasn't once affected gameplay. In fact, I am incredibly impressed with how well the controller and floor is tracked. It's very apparent when you're playing shooter type games where aiming matters a lot.

The main complaint I have is the Air Link feature to wirelessly connect to the PC did have issues at first. My desktop is in a different room than the router and connected wirelessly over AX. The signal is more than good enough for gaming, but I guess it just couldn't quite cut it when it came to streaming VR wirelessly. I ran an ethernet to the living room where the router is and it works near flawlessly now. I can even play the Oculus in other rooms (including where my PC is) and there's no issues either. It might just be something not quite optimized yet since Air Link is still in the beta phase right now.

Overall I really couldn't be happier. My wife and I had talked about getting a VR headset for years but never could quite pull the trigger, but for 300 dollars getting this as our first full VR headset was a no brainer. Love it!

First off, if you're considering waiting for a newer headset for the first time, just send it on this if it's going to be your first VR experience. The Quest 3 is still probably a year away, and getting the Quest 2 now is much more fun. Facebokk has millions of users on the Quest 2 so you know it'll be around and keep receiving updates for a long time. ONLY bad news that everyone knows is it does require a Facebook account (meaning the user account needs a signup age of 13+), but I don't mind that personally for this experience! I suggest playing for 15-30 minutes maximum for your first experience, so use the First Steps app to get used to it. (Even though I used it for the first 2 hours as my first time amd haven't got sick. Maybe using the Gear VR first helped with that). Comfort isn't bad if you use the new silicone cover and use the TOP STRAP to support your head mainly, but I highly recommend a new strap (the official Elite Strap is known for snapping so use a 3rd party) and facial interface (best from VRCover). If you want PCVR a cable can do while starting but wireless is where it's at. 
Wireless is a feature best for use under the conditions following:
At least a Wi-Fi6 router solely connected to your Quest wirelessly and PC with ethernet. (Around $80 for the router)
Potentially a power bank at the back if your strap for added playtime as the Quest 2 only has a 2 hour battery life (the power bank will add support to thr headset making it feel less front heavy, and will have less issues with battery degradation).
A new strap is recommended for longer play sessions, and a VRCover facial interface too.
The Oculus Rift app is required on your desktop for PCVR. 
SteamVR is your best bet for PCVR games. Although you have to use the Oculus Rift app in combination with SteamVR.

Lastly, take your time getting into VR (I know it is really, really fun!). You'll probably enjoy yourself more if you take your time and explore all the opportunities. Play how you want and enjoy!
Happy Questing!

Hands down one of the best purchases of 2020 for me was the Oculus Quest 2.  I bought a 256GB for myself, and recently this refreshed 128GB model for a friend.  The display, quality, and longevity have been top notch.  There are some rough patches on the journey, but overall the Oculus Quest 2 is how VR should be.

Overall the physical design is surprisingly light.  It's only slightly heavier than my first generation WMR headset.  Tracking is lightyears better than the Windows headset, and the display/resolution is just as good.  Optics are quite good for the price - this still represents a lower end headset, but most people will be impressed.  The Oculus is still immersive, but not in the same way as say the Index or other wide field of vision headset.

Controllers are smaller than what I was used to, but they're durable and easy to use for even smaller hands.  Triggers are responsive and easy to use, and the Oculus button allows you to re-center yourself easily.  Great usability because of that.

The wire free nature of the Oculus is one of the biggest selling features, and I can attest - after coming off of a WMR headset - that wire free is the way to go for most games.  It's just plain more immersive, and being able to swing away during beat saber is a million times better than worrying about a wire.  First party and exclusive games are ok, but the experience is great.

Oculus keeps updating the software, and features, flexibility, and battery life all seem to benefit.  I've been using the Quest 2 for over 9 months now, and I can attest to the software maturing and benefiting the user experience.  The ability to cast, and record is fun.

The included band is cheap and not very comfortable. The pro band lasted me like 2 months before breaking (I have a large head, and my kids small heads, so a lot of adjusting seems to have killed it).  Third party bands pretty much do the same thing, so I've resigned to replacing them every few months after they crack and break. 

Overall this is a great time.  Software isn't the cheapest, and this is not $4000 gaming PC, but overall the experience is top notch.  This is worth your time and money if you enjoy the game selection.

By far the best value in VR today, hands down. The fact that it works both standalone and tethered with a PC really makes it the best of both worlds...

Unfortunately I don't have a lot of good to say about VR in general.

Issues specific to this device design:
* It lacks focal adjustment, and the virtual focal distance is far enough away as to require corrective lenses for us near-sighted while using...
* Unless you have a tiny head with thin frames, your glasses will not fit - with or without the extension.
* Using without glasses isn't terrible, but not great
* Peripheral vision is blurry even with the lens separation properly adjusted.
* The head strap is also intended for people with tiny heads, and it doesn't do a very good job keeping the headset aligned with your eyes
* Head tracking performance degrades quickly if conditions are less than ideal (lower lighting, room isn't super clean)
* Playing VR is not and cannot be a social activity. It is inherently isolating, and not safe to use around other people unless you can trust them implicitly. The temptation to mess with a blindfolded person is too pervasive.

The Oculus Software / experience:
* Does not work well at all your feet aren't on the ground (recliner, bed for example)
* Basic accessibility features are lacking - what if your legs are paralyzed? What if you have balance issues and cannot stand with your eyes covered? What if you are missing an arm? What if you have tremors / neuropathy? Good luck typing lol
* You must show it where the floor is, and if you are seated your head hight will be wrong. An experimental option bumps up your head height... But there really needs to be a more basic "I cannot stand up with this thing on because of a disability"
* You cannot reset your view with respect to the ground. If you are in a reclined position it is nearly impossible to look at or reach thing on the ground.
* The only option for left-handed folks moves the oculus button, but the switch isn't honored by all apps
* Games are WAY too expensive. Don't believe the hype - VR isn't significantly harder to develop for that any other 3D. The excessive pricing is because of the "rich nerd" assumption and greed. Prices NEED to come down if they want people to embrace VR. VR doesn't stand up to marathon gaming - these games are going to be mostly on the casual / small bites side of things.

The headset is way to uncomfortable to wear longer then 2 hours
Been playing consistently for over 2 weeks and still get motion sickness fairly easily so at best I'm getting 2 hour gaming sessions before either the blood in my face is squeezed out and it feels bruised on my cheeks and forehead.
There are solutions to this but they're mostly third party.
On top of all this, everything has to be rebuilt instead of just transferred like a phone would be.
Instead of having the same apps as your phone, those same apps need to be rebuilt from the ground up, which means not only is there next to zero useful apps, but the ones you can find are entirely different from what they actually are on android or pc.
Instead of having one epic system, we have three slightly infinitely broken systems that can never be completed until they agree to be one system.

Be willing to jump through a lot of hoops to get things like basic android apps working and getting screen sharing with you computer working easily without some  serious modifications and know how.
2022 will hopefully changed this, but based on how the economy has been playing this out, I'd say they're going to take 10 years just to get N64 working again instead of just running android with the android store.

Aside from all this, its essentially the same game over and over rebranded and reskinned.
Either shooting games, tag games, or table tennis like games.

Some good experiences to be had, but not enough yet to make it worth a full fledge console price when you'll have to stretch to get 200 hours out of this thing when you can accidently dump that amount of time into a computer or game console without even realizing this.

Where as the Oculus will cause you a great deal of pain, discomfort, and anger over how annoying it is to use this headset as a virtual desktop

From the moment you turn it on you'll start having thoughts like:
Why isn't this done yet? Why can't I find this app? why doesn't this basic app that's over 15years old work properly? 
Why can I stream fast past games to kids around the world where we can real time shoot each other with guns, but I have to pay 150$ yearly subscription just to stream my screen to my headset? 

Why is it such a crap experience when streaming 3 feet to my headset?
I've been playing real time COD since I was 13 years old over wifi, yet some how, some way, it takes to much information to have real time updates with a computer 3 feet infront of me.

The Oculus Quest 2 is a neat glimpse into the future bogged down by a plethora of issues. Privacy concerns withstanding - as Meta is aiming to monitor every movement and facial expression one makes whilst using the device - there are many practical problems with the design of the device itself. It only has 3 different IPD settings, meaning that anyone whose IPD falls in between or outside of the presets will have an issue with blurring vision and an unclear image. This was a huge part of what I disliked about my experience with it, as it gave me significant headaches and visual distortion well after stopping use of the device. For clarity's sake, I used it for about 30 minutes at a time, once a day for a few days in a row.  Many people tend to complain about feeling motion sickness when using these devices and while I did feel a little goopy in the gut, I didn't enjoy the sensation of motion enough to get to where this was a serious issue for me. I grew up playing video games regularly and still do occasionally, so it was entertaining to see how I could interact with games in a 3D space. That being said, none of the games felt very satisfying, and these days if I want to play a video game I certainly don't want to be strapped into an uncomfortable near-eye projector to be fully engaged in the experience. The headstrap is a well-documented nightmare and it's absurd that they charge extra for a higher-quality one instead of changing out the one included. They finally added a silicone cover to the padding around the eyes after countless complaints about the foam irritating people's skin, and I'm not surprised as it feels kind of like fine sandpaper to the touch. What would have been the most relaxing experiences were dulled by low-resolution image quality (on a high-speed connection, no less) and in the case of multiplayer games, a disturbing amount of young players - well below the recommended age for using the device in the first place. It's a shame that parents don't monitor their kids better to prevent this from happening and instead slap them into a device that will invariably detriment their developing sense of balance and spatial recognition. Further still, it is disappointing that Facebook (now rebranded as Meta) has done so little to mitigate these issues. 

Ultimately, perhaps this product is merely not for me. However, I would recommend against it to anyone who is looking to use it for relaxation and absolutely insist that nobody use this for long periods as it can be dangerous - as is stated in the health and safety information included with the device.

Overall, I think the Quest 2 is a great VR headset as it provides a full VR experience without the requirement of a separate computer for a price far below any competitor.  This doesn't mean that the Quest 2 necessarily provides an overall better experience, but as someone that has used the Vive, Vive Pro, Quest, and Samsung Odyssey, it's hard to ignore how much simpler this is.  However, there are some worthwhile things to note for any prospective buyers:

1. Facebook did simplify the headset as a means to help reduce the cost.  For example, IPD adjustment is not as effective on the Quest 2 as it was on the Quest.  Interpupillary distance (IPD) refers to the space between your eyes, and it is important to get this value correct on your headset to avoid feeling like you're not staring cross-eyed.  The original Quest provided a granular slider with options from 58mm to 72mm.  The Quest 2 provides three settings: 58mm, 63mm, and 68mm, which are set via physically moving both lenses (at the same time) inward or outward where an indicator at the top center will display 1 (58mm), 2 (63mm) or 3 (68mm).  This change was a bit problematic for me, because my IPD is 71mm, so I always feel a little bit cross-eyed while using the Quest as I'm forced to stare a bit inward instead of straight ahead.

2. You should consider getting accessories to better the overall experience.  Probably the worst offender is that the provided strap is not terribly comfortable.  The issue is that the Quest 2's weight is all located in the headset, which means you want a robust strap to allow for the back of your head to help remove the weight from your face.  You can either consider the strap that Facebook sells separately or a strap from a third-party vendor.  Personally, I use the latter.  If you use glasses, I would also strongly consider getting prescription lens adapters, and if you don't, you can buy similar adapters with non-prescription lenses.  The non-prescription lens can help protect your Quest 2's lenses.

3. If you are planning for a child to use this, be aware that the Quest 2's software does NOT support parental controls.  Similarly, the Quest 2 currently requires a Facebook account, and if you would prefer that your child not use Facebook, you would need to create one for them to use with the Quest 2 or use your own.  Facebook/Oculus have stated that they are looking to remove this requirement, but as of writing, nothing has been announced as to when this will occur.

4. You can use the headset with a computer if you want.  The headset supports displaying computer-based VR either through a cable or wirelessly through WiFi.  Just be aware that wireless will depend heavily upon your WiFi signal in the area that you're trying to use for play.

In the end, I think the best way to look at the Quest 2 is that it provides a great VR experience for its price point.  It's easy to point out how a headset like the HTC Vive Pro or the Valve Index are arguably better in certain ways, but they also cost considerably more and have additional hardware and setup requirements.

I'm having a blast with this thing. There are some slight differences between this and the wired Oculus. 

You can't move around and decorate your home area (I really enjoyed that). 

I find downloading files a little irritating sometimes. If I select a game to download and then go plug it in, it promptly shuts itself down and stops the download. I have to leave it on and trick it by setting it on the chair, unplugged, and it usually downloads fine. 

The playtime is great for me but I'm a casual user and don't even like to play other games while I wait for the download, but I think I get a couple of hours of play out of a single charge. It takes forever to charge this thing, though. I'd have to guess, because I haven't timed it, but I probably get about one hour of play for every two hours of charge. 

It can be a little glitchy and I hate when it decides it can't find the internet but, if you compare it to the setup time on the original Oculus, that is almost petty in comparison. 

I was worried about getting the 128GB since the larger storage wasn't available but there's plenty of room to store a variety of games and, quite frankly, I've found that the games I like to repeat have to be removed and re-downloaded anyway. I don't know about all of them but the story games I like don't let you just wander back through your favorite chapters. For me, the extra space would be a waste so I'm glad this was all that was available. 

There are some great VR experience files for free and there are some free games too. The free games all look like multiplayer games, though. The most expensive games are around 30 bucks but some of them go on sale. There are cheaper games too and there are plenty of reviews on the internet for most of the games. There are reviews in the Oculus browser too, if you are inclined to trust those but, either way, you don't have to buy blind. AARP has a game bundle in the browser too so if you are looking for something for an older person who is trying to stay sharp, they can play this even if they aren't particularly mobile. 

Overall, this is AWESOME. I still wish they would allow you to download a home that is more like a stand alone game so you can interact with the environment. I'd even be willing to purchase a sim like home environment if they made them but, unfortunately, there doesn't seem to be any options for that.

The other thing I wish it had was an actual sample of the 3D movement before you buy the game. They do have previews of the game but until you purchase the game, you just can't tell if it's going to move in such a way that you become disoriented. I get motion sickness and there are games that I can definitely play and games that make me feel sick after .034 seconds. I feel like they should have a better way of making sure you are compatible with the game before you purchase it.  

You can't beat the price for what this does and how easy it is to use while it does it. For any glitch or inconvenience, the enjoyment of leaping into another world and being blown away by the detail and movement is indescribable. The sounds on this are great and I don't use earbuds, I just use the built in speakers. I've used this almost every day since I got it and it, literally, sweeps me off to another world where I am so engrossed that I can't help but relax for awhile. What a joy.

This is my first VR headset. I bought this one mostly because it's cheap, doesn't require base stations, and is able to be connected to a gaming computer to use SteamVR and such, rather than using it for the self-contained ability to play games. 

I didn't want to invest in a more expensive headset designed for gaming rig use, because I didn't want to drop more money on something that I may potentially not use due to the fact that I can get motion sickness pretty easily. I didn't want to deal with setting up base stations either, because it's not very convenient. I would've gotten the Rift S, but by the time I was in the market for a VR headset, they'd essentially discontinued it, unfortunately. As a result, this was my best option. 

It's pretty easy to figure out how to use. Strap it to your face, and do what the prompts tell you to get things set up, and then from there, if you want, you can hook it up to your rig. You simply plug a USB type C cable into the side of the headset, and the other end into the fastest USB port on your computer (it must be USB 3.1, if I'm not mistaken). 

So here's what's great about it: It's an excellent way of introducing yourself to the platform of VR without making a HUGE financial leap of faith, relative to other VR headsets anyways. You don't need a computer to use this, you simply need the headset and a phone in order to get things paired properly. There seems to be a decent selection of games that are compatible with it on the Quest app, most of the ones people would normally want to play, so there's no shortage of fun here. It's also really easy to let someone else try it out, if they've never had a VR experience. You don't need to drag someone to your place, or drag your gaming computer somewhere else, you can simply take the headset and a charger and you're good to go. I have only played it while connected to a computer, so I can't make any accurate comment on battery life, or performance in standalone mode, or anything like that, but I can say that this is a good value for people looking to get into the platform and figure out if it's the right thing for them. 
It was recently announced that there will no longer be a requirement to have a Facebook account in order to use it, if that's something that bothers you. It certainly bothered me for a while, at least. 

Here's the not so good things: The strap. The strap to keep this thing on your face is terrible. It's uncomfortable, it moves around way too much, it's not secure feeling, and adjusting it for other people to use it safely is a huge pain in the rear. You can purchase the elite strap, or some cheap knockoff of one, but the fact is that it comes with a garbage strap out of the box, and you'll need to pay more money to get one that doesn't suck. Given how cheap it is for VR, it's not that big of a deal, but it's definitely annoying, at the very least. 

The next thing is more of a complaint with VR as a platform rather than the headset, but the truth is that VR games are almost universally gimmicky. A gimmick isn't necessarily a bad thing, but VR games are more like arcade games than immersive, interesting experiences for the most part. There's certainly a few exceptions to this, but seriously, you're not going to find an immersive world or story in most of the games you'll come across (excluding ports, like Skyrim, for example). Beat Saber, Superhot, Pistolwhip and games like that are obviously fun, but there's really not much to them. It gets old quickly, and soon you don't play your headset for weeks at a time because when you've played the game enough, you're burnt out for a good while. 

This is, of course, not relevant to the headset itself, so I'm not counting it against the headset in the review or anything, but I felt it was something that you should be aware of if you're thinking of purchasing one. 

Overall, aside from the strap complaint, I think that this is a lovely headset for people who don't have a VR headset yet, and/or don't have a machine capable of running VR games. The strap is honestly really obnoxious to me which is why it cost the headset a star in this review, but that's not to say that this is a bad headset. It's definitely worth a try, at the very least!

For those of you concerned with motion sickness, by the way, here's my input. I get motion sickness pretty easily, and frankly, whether or not I feel sick with this depends solely on what game I'm playing or what I'm doing. I can play Beat Saber without an issue, but playing No Man's Sky made me feel horribly sick. Hanging around in the "hub" when you're not in a game made me very sick too. Playing Pavlov made me very sick. My mom put it on to try it out, and she got sick after about 45 seconds of looking around in the "hub" as well. In short, it depends on what game you're playing, and how prone you are to motion sickness to begin with.
